comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content:
160126 Sapper D S Salter was selected for officer training in 1917 and as an Officer Cadet was Commissioned as a Second Lieutenant into the Royal Garrison Artillery on 4th May 1917 [Supplement to London Gazette dated 10th May 1917].

Donald Sowerby Salter, b. 1890, was one of 9 children (2 daughters and 7 sons) of Mortyn John Salter and Alice (nee Wilding), m.1875, of 5 Stanhope Gardens, South Kensington.  Siblings were Eveline, b. 1876: Dorothy, b. 1877: John, b. 1879: Mortyn, b. 1880: Richard, b. 1882: Harold, b. 1884: Brian, b. 1889: and Frank, b. 1892.  Donald had followed his father into the British Rainfall Office.  Eveline was a headmistress and John a noted botanist.

126 Siege Battery went to France on 25 July 1916 equipped with four 8-inch howitzers pulled by Holt 75 caterpillar-tracked mechanised tractors.  In April 1917 the battery suffered significant casualties.  In July 1917 126 Siege Bty re-equipped with 6-inch howitzers.  The Battery Commander was Major Edwin Fry RGA, (dow May 1918); and the Battery Sergeant Major was originally BSM Harry Bridle, (kia 5 July 1917).//

comment.author: 68061336@N05
comment._content: Commonwealth War Graves Commission lists the following details SALTER, D S Rank: Second Lieutenant Date of Death: 22/03/1918 Age:28 Regiment/Service: Royal Garrison Artillery 126th Siege Bty. Grave ReferenceXI. A. 2. Cemetery GREVILLERS BRITISH CEMETERY Additional Information:Son of Mortyn John and Alice Salter, of Bank House, Mickleton, Campden, Glos. they can be found here www.cwgc.org/search-for-war-dead/casualty/291007/SALTER,%... A photography of his grave can be found here www.twgpp.org/information.php?id=2475604
